newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria capital account swings to deficit in Q1.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria capital account swings to deficit in Q1.

text.p: Bulgaria posted a capital and financial account deficit of $101.2 million in the first quarter of this year after a surplus of $217.1 million in first quarter 1996, central bank preliminary figures showed.

Portfolio investments rose $20.5 million in the first three months of this year, mainly because of increased foreign investment in government securities, against a fall of $37.2 million for the same period of 1996, the Bulgarian National Bank (BNB) said in a statement.
Foreigners bought $4.6 million worth of government securities and a further $43.3 million of bad debt bonds in the first three months of this year, figures showed.
Bulgaria received $90.5 million in principal payments on long-term loans to other countries in the first quarter.
Local commercial banks' deposits abroad rose by $98.6 million in the first quarter after falling $18.9 million in the same period last year.

Resident capital outflow in the first quarter totalled $23.5 million because of a lack of confidence in Bulgaria's shaky banking system and the sharp fall in the lev. The lev hit a record low of 3,000-3,200 per dollar in February.
Net principal payments on long-term and short-term loans from foreign lenders totalled $68.2 million in the first three months of this year against $129.5 million a year earlier.
BNB foreign exchange reserves rose by $35.1 million in the first quarter to $517 million, BNB figures showed.
